title: Angelic acid
text:
Angelic acid is a <a href="Carboxylic%20acid">monocarboxylic</a> <a href="Saturated%20and%20unsaturated%20compounds">unsaturated</a> <a href="organic%20acid">organic acid</a>, mostly found in the plants of the family <a href="Apiaceae">Apiaceae</a>. It is a volatile solid with a biting taste and pungent sour odor. It is the "<a href="Cis%E2%80%93trans%20isomerism">cis</a>" <a href="isomer">isomer</a> of 2-methyl-2-butenoic acid, which easily converts to the "trans" isomer, <a href="tiglic%20acid">tiglic acid</a>, upon heating or reaction with inorganic acids. The reverse transformation occurs much less readily. The salts and esters of angelic acid are called angelates. Angelic acid <a href="ester">ester</a>s are the active components of herbal medicine used against a wide range of various health disturbances including pains, fever, <a href="gout">gout</a>, heartburn, etc.
Name and discovery.
Angelic acid was first isolated by the German pharmacist Ludwig Andreas Buchner (1813–1897) in 1842 from the roots of the garden plant angelica ("<a href="Angelica%20archangelica">Angelica archangelica</a>"), which gave the acid its name.
Occurrence.
Angelic acid occurs in the roots of many plants, especially of the family <a href="Apiaceae">Apiaceae</a>. These plants include "<a href="Angelica%20archangelica">Angelica archangelica</a>", "<a href="Peucedanum%20ostruthium">Peucedanum ostruthium</a>" (masterwort), "<a href="Levisticum%20officinale">Levisticum officinale</a>" (lovage), "<a href="Euryangium%20sumbul">Euryangium sumbul</a>" and "<a href="Laserpitium%20latifolium">Laserpitium latifolium</a>". In the latter plant, it is present in the resin called <a href="Silphium%20%28antiquity%29">laserpicium</a>, and the oil of carrot also contains angelic acid. Sumbul plants might contain not angelic acid itself, but a larger complex which breaks into angelic acid upon processing. The acid can also be extracted from the oil of <a href="chamomile">chamomile</a> flowers, and 85% of Roman chamomile ("<a href="Anthemis%20nobilis">Anthemis nobilis</a>") oil consists of esters of angelic and tiglic acids; it also contains isobutyl angelate and amyl angelate. The acid content is highest in "Angelica archangelica" where it is about 0.3%.
Properties.
Angelic acid is a volatile solid with a biting taste and pungent sour odor. It crystallizes in colorless monoclinic prisms which dissolve rapidly in <a href="ethanol">alcohol</a> or hot water and slowly in cold water. Angelic and <a href="tiglic%20acid">tiglic acid</a> are "<a href="Cis%E2%80%93trans%20isomerism">cis</a>" and "trans" isomers of 2-methyl-2-butenoic acid, respectively. The former can be entirely converted to the latter by boiling for about 40 hours, by reaction with <a href="sulfuric%20acid">sulfuric</a> and other acids, by heating with a base to a temperature above 100 °C, or simply by storing the acid for about 25 years. The reverse transformation occurs much less readily; it can be induced by ultraviolet light, but not with visible light. The conversion rate is low and only 0.36 g of angelic acid could be obtained from 13 g of tiglic acid after 43-day irradiation with a 500-watt lamp. Being the "cis" isomer, angelic acid has a lower melting point and higher acid dissociation constant than tiglic acid, in accordance to usually observed trends. 
Angelic acid reacts with <a href="hydrobromic%20acid">hydrobromic acid</a> and bromine producing <a href="valeric%20acid">bromovaleric</a> and dibromovaleric acids, respectively, with a yield of 60–70%. Chlorovaleric and iodovaleric acids are obtained using <a href="hydrochloric%20acid">hydrochloric</a> and <a href="hydroiodic%20acid">hydroiodic acid</a>s, respectively. The salts of angelic acid are called angelates. Angelates of <a href="alkaline%20earth%20metal">alkaline earth metal</a>s "M" have a general formula M(C5H7O2)2 and form white, water-soluble crystals.
Applications.
The angelic acid esters of sesquiterpene alcohols, such as petasin, are the active chemical behind the strong pain-relieving and <a href="Muscle%20relaxant">spasmolytic</a> action of extracts from the plant <a href="Petasites">butterbur</a>. <a href="Anthemis%20nobilis">Roman chamomile</a>, in which esters of angelic and tiglic acids are the principal components, was used as a <a href="sedative">sedative</a> and tonic, and as a medicine against nervous problems, fever, colic, heartburn, loss of appetite, gout, headache and other health disturbances.
